did.abstract: The materials in the Paul McCracken Papers relate to his career as an economist and his tenure as a Professor at the University of Michigan's Business School. The collection includes correspondence, published papers, speeches, and newspaper clippings.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: The collection was donated by Paul W. McCracken (donor no. 5960) over the period of 1977-2006. Additions were received in 2010 and 2013.

accruals.p: No further additions to the records are expected.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open to research.

userestrict.p: Copyright is held by the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: [item], folder, box, Paul Winston McCracken papers, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: Paul Winston McCracken was born in Richland, Iowa on December 29, 1915. He graduated with a bachelor's degree from William Penn College in 1937, and then received both his master's degree and doctorate from Harvard in 1942 and 1948, respectively.

From 1937 until 1940, McCracken taught at Foundation School of Berea College. Between 1942 and 1943 he worked as an economist in the U.S. Department of Commerce. In 1943, he left the Commerce Department to become financial economist and director of research at the Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis. He remained in Minneapolis until 1948, when he moved to Ann Arbor to join the faculty of the University of Michigan's School of Business Administration.

Since coming to the University of Michigan, McCracken, in addition to teaching, has been active as a senior economic advisor to both private industry and government. In the private sector, he advised numerous corporations, and serves on the board of directors of firms as diversified as K-Mart Corporation, Detroit Edison and Texas Instruments. In government, his most notable appointments have been two periods of service on the President's Council of Economic Advisers. President Eisenhower named him a member of the Council in 1956, a position he held until 1959. In 1969 President Nixon appointed McCracken chairman of the CEA, a post McCracken held through 1971. McCracken has also served in a number of lesser governmental advisory posts.

scopecontent.p: The papers of Paul McCracken have been arranged into ten series: Personal, Correspondence, Publicity and Speeches, U.S. Dept. of Commerce National Economic Unit, President's Council of Economic Advisors, Papers, University Notes, Visual Materials, Wall Street Journal, Sound Recordings, and OV Material.

controlaccess.head: Subjects:
controlaccess.corpname: University of Michigan. School of Business Administration.

scopecontent.p: The Personal series is arranged alphabetically. It is comprised of personal papers including family letters, certificates, appointments, and invitations/programs from the White House.

did.unittitle: Appointment Certificate to the Board of Directors Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis, June 11, 1945
Commencement Programs Featuring McCracken as a Speaker, 1961-1980
University of Michigan Appointment and Relocation, 1947-1948

scopecontent.p: The Correspondence series makes up the great bulk of the collection It is arranged by date (usually by year or grouping of years) and then by last name of the sender or the first letter of a corporation. This series dates from 1959 to 2004 with a gap from 1964-1971. The researcher should note that although these chronological subseries might be dated (1985 for example), the files themselves will often contain documents both before and after that date. The correspondence in the series is wide ranging, but it primarily reflects McCracken's work as an economist, consultant, or corporate director. Unfortunately, correspondence from McCracken's years as presidential advisor is not part of the collection. See note at the end for their location.

scopecontent.p: The Publicity and Speeches series contains unpublished speeches as well as published speeches, and papers. Additionally, a large part of the series is dedicated to newspaper clippings and magazine articles containing publicity on McCracken's career at the Federal Reserve Bank, as a member of the U.S. Council of Economic Advisors, as a Professor at the University of Michigan and as an economic expert.

scopecontent.p: The U.S. Dept. of Commerce National Economic Unit series contains memoranda dating from McCracken's involvement with this unit.

The President's Council of Economic Advisors series contains a small file of McCracken memoranda from the period during the Eisenhower administration when he was a member of the Council. There is substantially more material from the period of his chairmanship of the CEA during the Nixon administration. Included are memoranda regarding federal economic policy, reports and studies, published materials and newspaper clippings.

scopecontent.p: The Papers series contains publications, notes, book reviews, and speeches spanning from 1952 until 1996. A large gap occurs between 1959 until 1968 and the bulk of the papers are from the 1970s and 1980s. The scope of the Papers series is quite broad and includes subjects of state, national, and international importance.

scopecontent.p: The University Lectures Notes series contains notes McCracken took in his time as a student, and notes and course material from his time as a professor. Most courses are labeled by the designated class number, though some are organized by class title. Three notebooks have no label of what they are for.

The Wall Street Journal series is made up of the complete collection of articles that McCracken submitted and had published in the Wall Street Journal between 1972 and 1995. Most files contain a printout of the article as well as the newspaper clipping of the article. They are organized in reverse chronological order.

scopecontent.p: The Visual Materials series is arranged alphabetically. It is comprised of photographs and moving images on videocassettes. Photographs of note include White House Official Photographs of a Council of Economic Advisors sessions at Camp David and in the Oval Office. Individuals featured include McCracken, Richard Nixon, George H. Bush, Sam Sturgis, and Alan Greenspan. Additional photographs which had been framed are organized chronologically. Another grouping includes signed photographs and groups, identified and unidentified and two signed political cartoons
